bibl.title: Plains Cree Texts
bibl.series: Publications of the American Ethnological Society, Volume XVI

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kîtahtawê ayîsiyiniwak êh-wîkicik , kîtahtawê ômis îtwêw pêyak nâpêw ; Once upon a time, as some people dwelt somewhere, a certain man spoke as follows;

seg.gloss: you may tell a few people;

p.seg: têpakohp kik-êhtasinânaw , itêw . seven of us shall go,” he told him.

seg.gloss: “Very well.”
“Two nights from now we shall set out.
We shall look for Blackfoot, to steal their horses when we find them.

p.seg: mâka wâpamikoyahkwâwi , wîh-kakwê-nipahikoyahkwâwi , kiyâna mîna ka-kakwê-nipahânawak , itêw . And if they catch sight of us and try to kill us, we shall try to kill them,” he told him.

seg.gloss: “Very well.”

p.seg: tâpwê êh-kîh-nîso-tipiskâyik sipwêhtêwak . Accordingly, after two nights they set out.

awa pêyak nâpêsis ôhtâwiya êh-okimâwiyit , misatimwah itêh êy-ayâyit , êkotêh ayâw , kâ-wâpamât êh-pimohtêyit ôhi kâ-sipwêhtêyit . A certain young boy, whose father was chief, was where the horses were, and saw them go off who were setting out.

êh-kitâpamât ,
miyâmay ê-sipwêhtêcik ! itêyihtam , When he looked at them, “Surely they are going off!” he thought;
acosisah êh-ayât awa nâpêsis , kêkâc âta wiya êh-oskinîkit awa nâpêsis ; at the age of having arrows was the boy, though, indeed, he was close to adolescence;

seg.gloss: “Oh, do let me go with them!”

p.seg: ômis îtêyihtam . That was his thought.
tâpwê pimitisahwêw . Accordingly he followed them.
itêh êh-otâkosiniyik , ê-wîh-minahoyit , wistah êkotê takohtêw . At the place they reached toward evening, as they were about to kill game, he too arrived.
namoya kiskêyimik ôhtâwiya ê-sipwêhtêt . His father did not know that he had gone off.

êkwah ôki nâpêwak kâh-minahocik , kâ-takohtêyit ôhi nâpêsisah , nisitawêyimêwak ôhtâwiyiwa êh-okimâwiyit . And those men, when they had killed game and the boy arrived, recognized him as the chief's son.
namoya nânitaw wîh-itêwak . They did not care to say anything to him.
êkos êh-kîsitêpocik , ê-wîh-mîcisocik , miyw-asamêwak ôhi nâpêsisah . So, when they cooked their meal and were about to eat, they gave the boy plenty of food.

seg.gloss: “Well, let us treat him kindly.

p.seg: kitôkimâminaw okosisah , itwêwak . He is our chief's son,” they said.
tâpwê êkotah nipâwak . Then they slept there.
êh-wâpahk sipwêhtêwak . The next morning they went on.
it ê-tipiskâyik kapêsiwak . Where they were by dark, they camped for the night.
mwêhci nikotwâsikwâw êh-kîh-nipâcik , môhkiciwanipêk itah êh-ayâyik , cîk êkotah mostoswah ayâyiwa . When they had slept six nights on the way, near a spring of water were some buffalos.

seg.gloss: “Now then, let one man go shoot them.

p.seg: nipahâcih , êkotah ka-kapêsinânaw , kik-ôsîhtâyahk ta-nîmâyahk , itêw . If he kills any, we shall camp there and prepare provisions for the march,” the leader told them.
tâpwê pêyak sipwêhtêw , ê-wih-kakwê-nipahât mostoswah . Accordingly one set out to kill buffalos.
têpwê nipahêw pêyak . He killed one.
cîkih êh-sakâyik êkwah itohtêwak ôki kotakak . The others went to a near-by grove.
êh-takohtêcik êkotah , âsay ôma kâ-pâskiswât mostoswah . When they got to it, he had already shot the buffalo.

pêhtamiyiwa ayahciyiniwah namoya wâhyaw êh-ayâyit , mitâtaht êy-ihtasiyit , mîn êyakonik nêhiyawah êh-ntonawâcik . The sound was heard by some Blackfoot who were not far from there, ten in number, themselves looking for Cree.
êkwah êyakonik wîh-kakwê-wâpamêwak ôhi nêhiyawa . They decided to take a look at the Cree.

pôtih wâpamikok nêhiyawak ôki kâ-wiyinihtâkêcik têpakohp kêy-ihtasicik êkwah awa pêyak nâpêsis , êkosi ayênânîw . And there they saw those Cree preparing their carcass, seven of them, with the boy, a total of eight.
tâpwê pê-nâciyôstâkwak ayahciyiniwah . Accordingly the Blackfoot crept up on the Cree.
namoya kiskêyimêwak . The latter did not know of their presence.
mêkwâc êh-wiyinihtâkêcik , nam êskw êh-nawacîcik , âsay pâskisokwak ôki nêhiyawak . While they were cutting up the game, before they had begun the roasting, the Blackfoot fired at the Cree.

oma kâ-sakâyik êkotah êh-itâmocik , pêyak pahkisin nêhiyaw , oskâtihk êh-tawahoht , êh-nâtwâpayiyik oskât . As they fled toward the wooded place, one of the Cree fell, his leg pierced by a bullet and broken.
ôki kâ-misikiticik nâpêwak tapasîwak . The grown men fled.

awa nâpêsis nakîw , ê-kisâtât ôhi kâ-kaskâtahomiht , êh-têpwêt ,
ahâ , nitôtêmitik , wîhtamawâhkêk nôhtâwiy : namoya niwîh-nakatâw awa . The boy stopped and stayed by the wounded man, crying, “Hey, friends, tell my father when you see him: I shall not leave this man.
kiyâm nistah nika-nipahikawin , itêw , êh-têpwêt . I don't care if I too am killed,” he told them, calling to them.

âsay wâhyaw êh-atimipahtâyit owîcêwâkaniwâwa , êkwah âhci pikoh êh-pâskisokocik ayahciyiniwah , âskaw môskîstawêw , âta wyah êh-pimwât . When their comrades had run far away, and the Blackfoot were still shooting at them, he took the offensive against them from time to time, firing at them.
êkwah awa kâ-kaskatahoht êwako simatapiw , wîstah êh-pâskiswât , wîstah êh-nôtinikêt ; And the man whose bone had been broken sat up, and he too fired at them, joining in the fight;

mâka nama kêkway kîh-nipahêwak , êh-mitâtasiyit , êkwah wiyawâw êh-nîsicik awa nâpêsis . but they did not succeed in killing any of them, for the others were ten, and they only two, one of them a boy.
ayisk owîcêwâkaniwâwa nakatisimikwak . For their comrades had left them behind.
piyisk pôyoyiwa ôh iyahciyiniwah , êh-kostikocik , ê-sipwêhtêyit . At last the Blackfoot, fearing them, gave up and went away.

êkwah awa nâpêsis iyikohk êh-wâpamât wâhyaw êh-atimohtêyit , êkwah itohtêw mohkiciwanipêkohk , itah êh-tipinawâyik êkotah êh-miskahk . Then the boy, as soon as he saw that they had gone far away, went to the spring and found a sheltered place.
êkwah ntawâpamêw ôhi kâ-kaskatahomiht . Then he went to the wounded man.
â , nimiskên itah t-ay-ayâyahk , itêw . “Come, I have found a place where we can stay,” he told him.

seg.gloss: “Oh, no, my boy! Do go home!
Your father is chief; he will grieve.
You will only suffer here.
My leg will not get well so very soon.

p.seg: kîwê ! itêw nâpêsisah . Go home!” he told the boy.

seg.q: â , namoya ! iyikohk miyw-ayâyani , kîwêyini , êkoyikohk nika-kîwân .
seg.gloss: “Oh, no! When you are well and go home, then I shall go home.

seg.q:
nôhtâwiy iyâcimocih ,
sôhkêyihtâkosiw awiyak , kâ-nakatisimimiht kêsâtâcih , êh-itwêt mâna nipêhtawâw ;
seg.gloss: Whenever my father tells stories, I always hear him say, 'One is counted a brave man, if one stays with those who have been left behind.'

p.seg: êwako ohci k-ô-wîh-kisâtitân , itêw . That is why I mean to stay with you,” he told him.
êkosi itohtêw awa nâpêsis ôhi wiyâsah ; Thereupon the boy went to where the meat was;
askêkin otinam , êkotah êh-otapêt ôh ôskinîkiwa , sakâhk êh-itohtahât . he took the hide, and on it dragged the young man to the grove of trees.
om îtah kâ-tipinawâyik ê-kîh-pêsiwât , êkwah wiyâsah awatâw . When he had brought him to the sheltered place, he fetched the meats.
mêstinam wiyâsah . He took all the meat.

êkwah kotawêw , êkwah êh-kîsitêpot ta-mîcisocik , êkwah mînah nipiy êh-otinahk wînâstakayêpicikanihk , ta-minihkwêyit ôhi nâpêwa . Then he built a fire and cooked, that they might eat, and drew water in the paunch, that the man might drink.
tâpwê minihkwêyiwa , êkwah êh-mîcisoyit . So the latter drank and ate.

êh-kîsi-mîcisot , êkwah miscikosah kâh-kîskataham êh-apisâsiniyikih , ôma kâ-pîkopayiyik oskât , êkotah êh-tahkopitamwât ôm ôskâtiyiw . When he had eaten, he hewed some small sticks to shape, putting a splint on his leg where it was broken.

êkosi êh-kîsi-tahkopitahk , êkwah osîhtâw wîkiwâw nîpiyah ohci , êkotah êh-ayât , êkwah êw-osîhtât kâhkêwakwah ana nâpêw , êkwah awah nâpêsis tahkih êh-asawâpit . When he had tied it up, he built a hut for them of leaves, where the man stayed, preparing dried meat, while the boy always kept a lookout.
piyis tipiskâyiw . At last it grew dark.
êkotah ay-ayâwak . They stayed there.

kîtahtawê , ayênâniw êy-ihtahto-tipiskâyik êkotah êh-ayâcik , kâ-wâpamât êh-niyânaniyit ayîsiyiniwah êh-pêc-âstamohtêyit . Presently, when they had been there eight nights, he saw five men coming toward them.

êh-ka-kitâpamât , âsay mâka êh-otâkosiniyik , pôtih itah k-âyâcik cîk êkotah kapêsiyiwa , êy-osîhtâyit wîkiyiw , tâpiskôc wâskahikan êh-itahâyit mistikwah . As he watched them, as it was evening, he saw them make a camp for the night near to where they were, building a shelter, placing trees in the shape of a wooden house.

êkwah kisiwâk ê-wîh-kakwê-osâpamât , ê-wîh-kakwê-nisitawêyimât kêkw ayisiyiniwah , pôtih iyahciyiniwah . And when he made an effort to see them at close range, to see what kind of people they were, he saw that they were Blackfoot.

êkosi itohtêw ; êkwah ôh ôwîcêwâkanah ômis îtêw :
mahtih kipâskisikan pêtâ . So he went there and said to his companion, “Please give me your gun.
ôtah kisiwâk mahîhkan êh-ayât , nika-pâskiswâw , itêw . I want to shoot a wolf that is close by here.”
êkwah êh-miyikot , êkwah itohtêw . When the other gave it him, he went there.
âsay tipiskâw . It was dark by this time.
êkwah êh-pônamiyit , pîhcâyihk êh-apiyit , nâciyostawêw . The others had made a fire and were sitting indoors; he crept up to them.
êkwah êh-otihtât , isi-niyânaniyiwa , êh-nâh-nawaciyit . When he got near them, they were five, a-roasting of meat.
nawasawâpamôw ; tânihi êh-miyohoyit , êwakoni pâskiswêw , ê-sâkowêt . He took careful aim; he shot at those who wore the best clothes, and gave a whoop.
nîsoyawêw . He hit two of them.

êh-tapasiyit nîso , êh-tâh-tawikisiniyit mistikohk , osâm ê-sêkihât , êyakonih mîna pimwêw ; While two fled, one kept bumping into things, so much had he frightened him; this one too he shot; LB on {nîso}: Evidently I here missed the word {pêyak}: “one (of them)”.
nipahê mina . he killed him too.
êkosi nistoh nipahêw . So he had killed three.
nîs ôki tapasîwak . The other two fled.

êh-kiskêyihtahk êh-tapasiyit ; pîhtokêw , otayôwinisiyiwa êh-otinahk , mîna pâskisikan pêyak , pêyak acosisah , pêyak cîkahikani-pakamâkan , êkwah pêyak câpîhcicikanis , môhkomânah nêwo , mîna ostikwâniyihk ôtah ôma êh-manisamwât . When he saw that they had fled, he went inside and took their garments, and a gun, a set of arrows, a tomahawk, and a lance, and four knives, and he cut off this, on their heads here.

kahkiyaw omaskisiniyiwa otinam , êkwah êh-kîwêhtatât , ôhih kâ-kaskatahomiht wîcêwâkanah , êh-pîhtokatât , êh-miyât . He took all their moccasins, and took it all back with him and gave it, when he brought it into their hut, to his wounded companion.

mistahi mâmaskâtamiyiwa ,
tântah êh-ohtinaman ? êh-itikot . He was much surprised, and asked him, “Where did you get it all?”
êh-niyânanicik otah ê-kapêsicik ayahciyiniwak , nisto ninipahâwak , êkotah ôhi êy-ohtinamân , itêw ; “Five Blackfoot camped here for the night; I killed three of them and took these,” he told him;

seg.gloss: “I suppose you heard gunshot.”
“Yes.”
That was when I shot two of them.

seg.q: êkwah pêyak osâm êtokê ê-sêkisit , êh-tâh-tawikisihk , min êwako nipimwâw ; ninipahâw .
seg.gloss: And one, I suppose because he was frightened, bumped into things, and I shot him too; I killed him.
That makes three.”

p.seg: tâpwê , wêskinîkiyin , namoya kikostâwak ! itik . “Really, young man, you do not seem to be afraid of them!” the other said to him.
miywêyihtam awa nâpêw . The man was glad.
piyis êkotah ay-ayâwak . Then they stayed there.
namoya ês ôma wâhyaw êh-wîkiyit . Now, it seems that those others had their camp not far from there.
ôki kâ-tapasîcik ayahciyiniwak takosinwak wîkiwâhk ; Those Blackfoot who had fled arrived at their camp;
âcimowak êh-nipahihcik , wiyawâw piko êh-pimâtisicik . they told how their comrades had been slain, and that only they were alive.
ê-kîh-nêwo-tipiskâyik , kîtahtawê kâ-pêtisâpamât , êh-pâpiciyit ayahciyiniwah . After four nights, there, the boy saw the Blackfoot coming, moving up their camp.
êkwah êkotah ohci ka-kitâpamêw , kisiwâk êkotah kâ-pê-kapêsiyit , êh-mihcêtiyit . From where he was, he watched them, as they came to pitch camp close by, a great number of them.
êkwah pê-nâtimâwa ôhi kâ-kîh-nipahât , êh-kîwêhtayimiht . And those whom he had killed were fetched and taken back.
ka-kitâpamêw . He continued to watch them.
piyisk t-ati-tipiskâyiw . At last darkness came on.
iyikohk mistah êh-tipiskâyik , itohtêw owîcêwâkanah . When it was quite dark, he went to where his companion was.

seg.gloss: “You had better not light any fire.

seg.q: kêkway niwâpahtên ; mâka namoya nikiskêyihtên kêkway .
seg.gloss: I see something; but I do not know what it is.

p.seg: mahtih nika-kakwê-nisitawihtên , itêw . I think I shall go try to hear what it is,” he told him.
êkosi min êh-sipwêhtêt , mîkiwâhpihk êh-itohtêt . With that he went off again, and went to the camp.
mitâtaht misatimwa otinêw , êh-kimotamawât iyahciyiniwah . he took ten horses, stealing them from the Blackfoot.
otihtêw owîcêwâkanah . He came back to his companion.

seg.gloss: “Now then, comrade, what shall we do?
It seems that Blackfoot are camping close by;

seg.q: mâka âsay mitâtaht otêmiwâwa ôtah nipêsîmâwa !
seg.gloss: in fact I am bringing ten of their horses now!”

p.seg: kika-kîwânânaw , ka-tapasiyahk , itêw ; “We shall go home, making our escape,” he said to him;

seg.gloss: “They will not be able to pursue us;

p.seg: namoya mihcêt misatimwak , êh-itât . the horses are not many,” he told him.

tâpwê pêyak pê-takohtahêw wîkiwâhk , êkwah êh-wayawîtâcimoyit owîcêwâkanah , êh-oyahpitât otakohpisiwâwa ohci , êh-têhtahât owîcêwâkanah . Accordingly he brought one of the horses to their hut, dragged out his companion, tied him up with their blanket-robes, and set him on the horse.

seg.q: hâ , niwîcêwâkan , kiya kinakacihtân nîkân ohci .
seg.gloss: “Now, comrade, you know how to lead.
I shall drive on the horses.

p.seg: mîna ka-kiskêyihtên tân-êyikohk ka-pimipayiyin , kiskât ôma ka-manâcihtâyin , itêw . Besides, you will know how far to ride without injuring your leg,” he told him.
mistahi miywêyihtam aw ôskinîkiw , êkwah ê-sipwê-têhtapit , ê-pê-sîhkitisahwâyit ôhi nâpêsisah misatimwah . The young man was very glad, and rode away, while the boy drove on the horses.
kapê-tipisk pimipayiwak . They rode all night.

êh-kîsikâyik , êh-wâpamât ôw ôskinîkiw misatimwah ,
tâpwêh miyosiwak ! itêyihtam . When day came and the young man saw the horses, “Really, they are fine ones!” he thought.
kapê-kîsik pimâmôwak , mîna kapê-tipisk . They fled all day, and again all night.
nîsotipiskwah namoya nipâwak . For two nights they did not sleep. CHECK tipiskwah
êkoyikohk êh-wâpamâcik mostoswah , nawaswêw awa nâpêsis . Then, as they saw some buffalos, the boy gave chase.
nipahêw pêyak . He killed one.
miywêyihtam aw ôskinîkiw , êkotah ê-nîhtakosît , ê-wîh-wiyanihtâkêcik , ê-wîh-mîcisocik . The young man was glad; he dismounted, and they skinned it and cut it up and made ready to eat.

âsay ôtêh wîkiwâhk awa nâpêsis êkwah aw ôskinîkiw mawîhkâtâwak ,
nipahâwak , êh-itihcik , ôhih ka-kîh-nakatisimikocik êh-itâcimowit . Meanwhile, back in their home, this boy and this young man were being mourned; “They were killed,” was said of them, in accordance with the story of those who had abandoned them.
tahkih mâtôyiwa ôhtâwiya awa nâpêsis k-ôkimâwiyit ohtâwiya . The boy's father, the chief, wept incessantly.

êkwah wiyawâw ê-kisi-wiyanihtâkêcik , êkwah êh-kîsitêpocik , êh-paminawasocik , êyikohk êh-kîsi-mîcisocik , mîna sipwêhtêwak . But, as for them, when they had cleaned their game, and cooked their meal, and eaten, they went on.
nîswâw êh-nipâcik , kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahkik wîkiwâwa . After two nights on the way, presently they came in sight of their camp.
miywêyihtam awa kâ-kih-kaskatahoht . The one who had been wounded was glad.

ispîh êh-wâpamihcik , êh-pê-sipwêpayit pêyak oskinîkiw , awînik ôk êyakonik ,
nipahâwak , kâ-kîh-itwêt . When they were seen, a young man came to them from the camp; whom did he see, but those of whom it had been said that they were killed! LB on {kâ-kîh-itwêt}: Probably read as {kâ-kîh-itwêhk}: “it was so reported”, as in translation.

êkotah ohci kîwêpayiw awa , êh-ntawi-wîhtamawât ôh ôkimâwa êh-takosiniyit okosisiyiwa mîn ôhi kâ-kîh-kaskatahomiht , Then this man rode back to tell the chief that his son had come home, as well as the man who had been wounded;
êy-isi-pêhtahkik , êh-ntawi-nakiskawâcik . and when they heard this, they went to meet them.

êh-pêtastimwêyit aw ôkosisah , okimâwa , awa nâpêsis ôhih kâ-kaskatahomiht niyânan miyêw misatimwah ; That boy, the chief's son, who brought the horses, gave five of them to the man who had been wounded;
wiya mîna niyânan ayâwêw misatimwah . five horses he kept.
mistahi miywêyihtam aw ôkimâw . The chief was very glad.

mîna ayahciyiniwah nisto êh-nipahât awa nâpêsis , miywêyihtamwak ôk âyisiyiniwak , êh-miyawâtahkik , êh-nimihitocik , awaw ohci nâpêsis osâm ê-sôhkêyimiht ,
tâpwê nâpêhkâsôw ! êy-itêyimiht , ôhi mîna nâpêwa êh-kaskatahomiht êkâ kâ-wîh-nakatât , osâm namoya cêskwa mitoni êh-oskinîkit . also because the boy had slain three Blackfoot those people were glad, and celebrated the outcome with a dance, thinking that boy very brave, thinking of him, “Truly, he is a brave warrior!” especially because he had refused to abandon the wounded man, even though he was not yet full-grown.
êyakw ânima ohci k-ôh-miywêyihtahkik ayîsiyiniwak . That was why those people were glad.
êkoyikohk êskwâk âcimowin . This is where the story ends.
